RelatedSentence: THE South African Police Service ( SAPS ) did not have the power to investigate claims of crimes against humanity committed in Zimbabwe if the perpetrators were not in South Africa , it was argued in the Constitutional Court on Monday .
The case centres on whether the government is legally allowed to investigate such crimes outside South Africa 's borders .

The court heard arguments on whether the Implementation of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court Act would allow South African authorities to investigate claims of torture against senior Zimbabwean officials if the officials were not in South Africa .

RelatedSentence: The case started in 2008 when the Southern African Litigation Centre and the Zimbabwe Exiles Forum presented a docket to the National Prosecuting Authority 's priority crimes litigation unit detailing acts of torture allegedly committed after a raid by Zimbabwean police on the headquarters of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change .

In 2012 , a South African high court ordered the police to investigate the claims .
